If not, we should figure out how to return a success result anyway. If it does and somehow it's returning a different attribute name than the one we submitted perhaps we need to return an error...

nodes.bodyText: Hmm - this message is not always accurate. I would remove the "since user is not authenticated" piece since there could be other reasons it fails (e.g. no internet) and then per Jameson's suggestion set the suggestion parameter below to "Ensure that you are logged in and online." instead of "See attached exception..."

If the user reached this success callback, that means they sent an attribute to update which Cognito accepted and successfully updated. We certainly don't want to throw an error in that case.
Also, Cognito supports custom attributes in addition to the standard ones we have listed so we don't know whether an attribute is valid or not - hence you can't have a working isValidUserAttribute method.

This isn't the best way to handle this because what if Cognito adds verification methods for other attributes in the future? What we know is that the onResult method only gets called if all attributes (in this case just the one) are updated successfully. The result object contains an entry if that attribute needs to be confirmed with a code and contains no entry if the update is complete and nothing more needs to be done. So the logic here for updating one attribute should be as simple as:
onResult:
if(result.size() == 0) return result with DONE status
else return result with CONFIRM_ATTRIBUTE_WITH_CODE status
onError:
return error

Similar to above, the logic inside the onResult method should go something like this:
Create a resultMap<AuthUserAttributeKey, AuthUpdateAttributeResult> object upfront.
Loop through the objects inside the result object and add them to a codeDetailsMap<String, UserCodeDeliveryDetails> keyed by the attribute string name so you can easily check whether a given attribute exists in it.
Loop through each attribute in the attributes list and for each one:
If it exists in the codeDetailsMap add an entry for it to resultMap with a status of CONFIRM_ATTRIBUTE_WITH_CODE
else add an entry to resultMap for it with a status of DONE.
There's no way there can be an error if we're inside the onResult callback.

So I actually think a better option here is to remove this check. If it comes back with a successful response, it means it recognized the attribute you sent and resent the code for it. You can simply return the converted response without checking this.
Both these two methods can be removed given my comments above.

This also can be removed now - this is not a list of valid user attribute keys - it's simply a list of the standard ones we provide for convenience. Because Cognito supports custom keys we can't know client side whether an attribute is valid or not (neither do we need to know).

nodes.bodyText: What is this loop for?

Defining a singleton map here defeats the purpose of having a map. My suggested logic was to do a loop through the UserCodeDeliveryDetails in result and add them all to a map before looping through the attributesMap to avoid having a nested loop like this one. In addition, this will add duplicate result entries for each non-verifiable attribute.
Good catch - thanks for fixing this.
"and get to fetch the user attributes" ?? looks like you were starting to type something else and didn't finish

To properly test this method as contrasted with the previous one, you should test passing in another attribute as well which doesn't get UserCodeDeliveryDetails back and verify that the correct result object gets created for it with a DONE status.
Just out of curiosity what was the reason behind changing the order of this method?
